title: Look-alike (Homoglyph) Domains
body: Attackers often register fake domains that look almost identical to real ones. They might replace letters with similar-looking characters (e.g., amaz0n.com instead of amazon.com).
tips: Always double-check URLs before entering credentials
Look closely for subtle spelling differences

check.question: Which of these is a fake domain?
check.explanation: Attackers use similar-looking characters to trick you.

title: Header Analysis
body: Email headers can reveal the real sending domain and servers used. Phishing emails often have suspicious or mismatched 'Received' paths and 'Return-Path' addresses.
tips: Look for mismatched domains or unexpected senders

check.question: Why check the 'Return-Path' field?
options: It reveals the actual sending domain
check.explanation: Return-Path shows where the email actually originated.

title: QR Code Phishing (Quishing)
body: QR codes can hide malicious links. Attackers send emails with QR codes leading to fake login pages to bypass URL scanners.
tips: Treat QR codes like links — verify before scanning
If unsure, use your official app instead of scanning

check.question: Why can QR codes be dangerous?
options: They always redirect to legitimate sites
They can’t be scanned on phones
check.explanation: QR codes can mask phishing URLs to trick scanners and users.

title: Spear-Phishing
body: Spear-phishing targets specific individuals with personalized information. These messages often seem legitimate because they use details the attacker already knows.
tips: Be cautious even if a message uses personal details
Verify through a trusted channel before acting

check.question: What makes spear-phishing harder to detect?
options: It uses personal info to look legitimate
check.explanation: Spear-phishing feels authentic because it’s tailored.
